United States Department of State / Foreign relations of the United States : diplomatic papers, 1945. General : the United Nations
			(1945)

 The United Nations conference on international organization, San Francisco, California, April 25-June 26, 1945, pp. 1-1432
			
 PDF (565.5 MB) 



Page 603


UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE
 PRESS STATEMENT
 MR. STsrnriius then asked for opinions as to the draft press release
-which had been distributed at the previous meeting to cover the pre-
sentation of the joint Four-Power amendments....
 This revised wording was agreed to by the four Foreign Ministers.Y8
It was also agreed that it would be acceptable if the Secretary of the,
United States Delegation presented this statement to the Conference
Secretariat along with the amendments -at the time that! they were
submitted.
 PREAMBLE
 As the meeting was closing, MR. MOLOTOV inquired as to the opinions
of the other three Delegation's on the question of a Preamble for the
Charter. MR. ST wnNrus said that the United States Delegation
thought such a Preamble would be highly desirable, and MEssRS. EDEN
and SOONG also agreed. It was pointed out that Field Marshal Smuts
had already submitted a suggested Preamble and for that reason it was
felt unnecessary to submit an additional one. Instead the four Dele-
.gations could take as a basis for their later discussions the draft ver-
sion submitted by the Field MarshalY9 This was agreed to.
 The session adjourned at 1: 10 p. m.-

of delegations of the United States, United Kingdom, Soviet;Union,
and China, together with an indefinite number. ofunnamed delegates,
'advisers and experts, of each delegation.]
 *In opening the meeting, MR. S.MTINrus asked whether the sub-
Committee had completed its work in the consideration of the pro-
posed amendments to Chapter V, Section B, paragraph 6, and Chap-
ter VIII, Section C, paragraph 2.

infor-
mation on the drafting of the preamble, see Report on the Conference held
at,
